    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-coexistence.md?ref=de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,166 @@\n+---\n+title: Security Service Edge (SSE) Coexistence With Microsoft and Cisco Umbrella\n+description: Microsoft and Cisco’s Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence solution guide.\n+author: kenwith\n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: conceptual\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.subservice: entra-private-access \n+ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco Umbrella DNS protection\n+\n+Learn how to deploy Global Secure Access and Cisco Umbrella, with DNS security only, in a unified environment. This guide provides step-by-step instructions for configuring both platforms to enhance security and connectivity as part of your Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) strategy.\n+The configurations outlined apply to both Cisco Umbrella and Cisco Secure Access. Detailed instructions for configuring each portal are provided.\n+> [!NOTE]\n+   > These scenarios feature DNS security only. If you want to include Cisco's Secure Web Gateway, see the coexistence configurations in the [Cisco Secure Access guide](how-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md).\n+## Scenarios\n+\n+This guide covers the following coexistence scenarios:\n+\n+1. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security](#1-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-entra-microsoft-access-with-cisco-umbrella-dns-security).**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles Internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco Umbrella provides DNS security. Cisco Secure Web Gateway features should be disabled.\n+2. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.](#2-microsoft-entra-internet-access-microsoft-access-and-microsoft-entra-private-access-with-cisco-umbrella-dns-security)**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles Internet, Microsoft, and Private Access traffic. Cisco Umbrella handles DNS. Cisco Secure Web Gateway should be disabled.\n+\n+ \n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+1. Cisco SWG features must be disabled for these configurations.\n+1. Integration with Microsoft Entra ID is recommended for best user experience.\n+\n+### Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+To configure Global Secure Access:\n+\n+1. **Enable or disable traffic forwarding profiles** for your Microsoft Entra tenant.  \n+    See [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+2. **Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector** for Private Access applications.  \n+    See [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+3. **Configure Quick Access** to private resources and set up Private DNS and DNS suffixes.  \n+    See [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+4. **Install and configure the Global Secure Access client** on end-user devices.  \n+    See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md).\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Private Network Connectors are required for Private Access applications.\n+\n+### Cisco Umbrella setup\n+\n+To configure Cisco Umbrella:\n+\n+1. **Provision users and groups.**  \n+    Integration with Microsoft Entra ID is recommended. See Microsoft Entra ID SAML configuration guide for [Umbrella](/entra/identity/saas-apps/cisco-umbrella-tutorial) or [Cisco Secure Access](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-users-and-groups).\n+2. **Create a policy to block a destination or content for testing.**\n+    For detailed information, see [Umbrella policies](https://docs.umbrella.com/deployment-umbrella/docs/create-and-apply-policies) or [Cisco Secure Access Internet Access Rules documentation](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-internet-access-rules).\n+3. **Deploy and install the Cisco Secure Client.**  \n+    \n+  > [!IMPORTANT]\n+  > Cisco released a Cisco Secure Client (CSC) feature to improve coexistence with Global Secure Access. These steps need to be performed after the initial installation, or re-installation (not required to run again when upgrading), of CSC version 5.1.10.x (or later). \n+  > 1. Install Cisco Secure Client version 5.1.10.x.\n+  > 1. Open CMD prompt as an administrator and run these commands:\n+  > 1. `\"%ProgramFiles(x86)%\\Cisco\\Cisco Secure Client\\acsocktool.exe\" -slwm 10`\n+  > 1. `net stop csc_vpnagent && net stop acsock && net start csc_vpnagent`\n+\n+## Bypass configuration for coexistence\n+\n+### Bypass Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access required IPs in Global Secure Access\n+\n+1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+2. Under **Internet access policies**, select **View**.\n+3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+4. Enter the following IPs: `208.67.222.222, 208.67.220.220, 67.215.64.0/19, 146.112.0.0/16, 155.190.0.0/16, 185.60.84.0/22, 204.194.232.0/21, 208.67.216.0/21, 208.69.32.0/21`\n+5. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access\n+\n+#### [Cisco Umbrella Portal](#tab/cisco-umbrella-portal)\n+\n+1. Add domain suffixes and Microsoft Entra service FQDNs to the **Deployments > Configuration > Domain Management > Internal domains** list: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Umbrella supports implied wildcards, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+2. Add these Microsoft FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+3. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+  > [!NOTE]\n+  > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+4. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+5. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+#### [Cisco Secure Access Portal](#tab/cisco-secure-access-portal)\n+\n+1. Go to **Connect > End User Connectivity > Internet Security**.\n+2. In **Traffic Steering**, select **Add Destination > Bypass Secure Access**, add this FQDN, and save: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Secure Access has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+3. Add these Microsoft FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+4. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+5. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+6. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+## Configuration scenarios\n+\n+### 1. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure the required destinations bypasses. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-umbrellacisco-secure-access) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Disable the SWG for [Umbrella devices](https://docs.umbrella.com/umbrella-user-guide/docs/selective-enablement#disable-the-swg-module) or [Cisco Secure Access devices](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/edit-roaming-devices-internet-security-settings#disable-the-internet-security-settings).\n+1.  Install and configure Cisco Secure Client software with the Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `yelp.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do not** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites in the traffic tab.\n+    4. In the Umbrella or Cisco Secure Access portal, validate DNS traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourmicrosoftdomain>.sharepoint.com` in browsers.\n+    6. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites. \n+    7. Access a site blocked by Cisco and validate that the Cisco block page is displayed.\n+    8. In Global Secure Access, stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+### 2. Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Umbrella DNS security.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Internet Access, Microsoft Access, and Private Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install a private network connector.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and Private DNS.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure the required destinations bypasses. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Umbrella/Cisco Secure Access](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-umbrellacisco-secure-access) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Disable the SWG for [Umbrella devices](https://docs.umbrella.com/umbrella-user-guide/docs/selective-enablement#disable-the-swg-module) or [Cisco Secure Access devices](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/edit-roaming-devices-internet-security-settings#disable-the-internet-security-settings).\n+1. Install and configure Cisco Secure Client software with the Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `yelp.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **don't** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites in the traffic tab.\n+    4. In the Umbrella or Cisco Secure Access portal, validate DNS traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourmicrosoftdomain>.sharepoint.com` in browsers.\n+    6. Verify Global Secure Access client **is** capturing traffic for these sites. We **do** expect to see destination FQDN information for these sites. \n+    7. Access a site blocked by Cisco and validate that the Cisco block page is displayed.\n+    8. Access a Microsoft Entra private application (for example, SMB file share) and validate that Global Secure Access **is** capturing traffic and Cisco isn't.\n+    9. In Global Secure Access, stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For troubleshooting health check failures, see [Troubleshoot the Global Secure Access client: Health check](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md).\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)"
  },

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md?ref=de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,239 @@\n+---\n+title: Security Service Edge (SSE) Coexistence With Microsoft and Cisco Secure Access\n+description: Microsoft and Cisco’s Secure Access coexistence solution guide.\n+author: kenwith\n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: conceptual\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.subservice: entra-private-access \n+ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco Secure Access\n+\n+Learn how to configure Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence using Global Secure Access and Cisco Secure Access.\n+\n+In today's digital landscape, organizations need robust, unified solutions for secure and seamless connectivity. Global Secure Access and Cisco Secure Access offer complementary Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) capabilities. When integrated, these platforms enhance security and connectivity for diverse access scenarios.\n+\n+This guide outlines how to configure and deploy Global Secure Access solutions alongside Cisco Secure Access SSE offerings. By using both platforms, you can optimize your organization's security posture while maintaining high-performance connectivity for private applications, Microsoft 365 traffic, and internet access.\n+\n+## Scenarios\n+\n+This guide covers the following coexistence scenarios:\n+\n+1.  **[Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access](#1-microsoft-entra-private-access-with-cisco-secure-internet-access).**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles private application traffic. Cisco Secure Internet Access provides DNS security and SWG capabilities.\n+\n+2.  **[Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access](#2-microsoft-entra-private-access-with-cisco-secure-internet-access-and-cisco-secure-private-access).**\n+In this scenario, both clients handle traffic for separate private applications. Global Secure Access handles private applications in Microsoft Entra Private Access, while the Cisco Secure Client - Zero Trust Access module handles private applications in Cisco Secure Private Access. Web and DNS traffic is protected by Cisco Secure Internet Access.\n+\n+3.  **[Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access](#3-microsoft-entra-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-internet-access-and-cisco-secure-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access manages all Microsoft 365 traffic. The Cisco Secure Client - Zero Trust Access module handles private applications in Cisco Secure Private Access. Web and DNS traffic is protected by Cisco Secure Internet Access.\n+\n+4.  **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Private Access](#4-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access manages internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco Secure Access handles only Private Access with the Cisco Secure Client - Zero Trust Access module.\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+To configure Global Secure Access and Cisco Secure Access for a unified SASE solution:\n+\n+- Set up Global Secure Access (Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Private Access).\n+- Configure Cisco Secure Internet Access and Secure Private Access.\n+- Establish required FQDN and IP bypasses for integration between the platforms.\n+\n+## Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. **Enable and disable different traffic forwarding profiles** for your Microsoft Entra tenant. See [Traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+1. **Install and configure the private network connector** for Private Access applications. See [Configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+1. **Configure Quick Access** to private resources and set up private DNS and DNS suffixes. See [Configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+1. **Install and configure the Global Secure Access client** on end-user devices. See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md).\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Private Network Connectors are required for Private Access applications.\n+\n+## Cisco Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. **Set up a resource connector** for private applications. See Cisco documentation for [managing resource connectors and connector groups](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-resource-connectors-and-connector-groups).\n+1. **Provision users and groups**. Integration with Microsoft Entra ID provides the best user experience. See Cisco documentation for [Microsoft Entra ID SAML configuration](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/configure-azure-for-saml).\n+1. **Add private resources and create access policies**. See Cisco documentation for [managing private access rules](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-private-access-rules).\n+1. **Set up internet security and configure bypasses** for coexistence. See Cisco documentation for [managing internet security](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-internet-security).\n+1. **Install and configure the Cisco Secure Client**. See Cisco documentation for [downloading and installing the client for Windows and macOS](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manual-installation-of-cisco-secure-client-windows-and-macos).\n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> Cisco released a Cisco Secure Client (CSC) feature to improve coexistence with Global Secure Access. These steps need to be performed after the initial installation, or re-installation (not required to run again when upgrading), of CSC version 5.1.10.x (or later).\n+> 1. Install Cisco Secure Client version 5.1.10.x.\n+> 1. Open CMD prompt as an administrator and run these commands:\n+> 1. `\"%ProgramFiles(x86)%\\Cisco\\Cisco Secure Client\\acsocktool.exe\" -slwm 10`\n+> 1. `net stop csc_vpnagent && net stop acsock && net start csc_vpnagent`\n+\n+## Bypass configuration for coexistence\n+\n+### Bypass Cisco Secure Access/Umbrella required IPs and FQDN in Global Secure Access\n+\n+1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+2. Under **Internet access policies**, select **View**.\n+3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+4. Enter the following IPs:\n+    `208.67.222.222, 208.67.220.220, 67.215.64.0/19, 146.112.0.0/16, 155.190.0.0/16, 185.60.84.0/22, 204.194.232.0/21, 208.67.216.0/21, 208.69.32.0/21`\n+5. Add a rule for the destination: `*.zpc.sse.cisco.com`\n+6. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access/Umbrella\n+\n+#### [Cisco Secure Access Portal](#tab/cisco-secure-access-portal)\n+\n+1. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, go to **Connect > End User Connectivity > Internet Security**.\n+2. In the **Traffic Steering** section, select **Add Destination > Bypass Secure Access**, add the following FQDN, and save: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Secure Access has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+3. Add these Microsoft 365 FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+4. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+5. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+6. In the Traffic Steering section, select **Add Destination > Bypass web proxy only**, add these IPs, and save: `150.171.19.0/24, 150.171.20.0/24, 13.107.232.0/24, 13.107.233.0/24, 150.171.15.0/24, 150.171.18.0/24, 151.206.0.0/16, 6.6.0.0/16`\n+7. Add these Microsoft 365 IP addresses (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `132.245.0.0/16, 204.79.197.215/32, 150.171.32.0/22, 131.253.33.215/32, 23.103.160.0/20, 40.96.0.0/13, 52.96.0.0/14, 40.104.0.0/15, 13.107.128.0/22, 13.107.18.10/31, 13.107.6.152/31, 52.238.78.88/32, 104.47.0.0/17, 52.100.0.0/14, 40.107.0.0/16, 40.92.0.0/15, 150.171.40.0/22, 52.104.0.0/14, 104.146.128.0/17, 40.108.128.0/17, 13.107.136.0/22, 40.126.0.0/18, 20.231.128.0/19, 20.190.128.0/18, 20.20.32.0/19`\n+8. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+#### [Cisco Umbrella Portal](#tab/cisco-umbrella-portal)\n+\n+1. Add domain suffixes and Microsoft Entra service FQDNs to the **Internal domains** list: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Umbrella supports implied wildcards, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+2. Add these Microsoft 365 FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+3. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`   \n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+4. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+5. In the **External Domains & IPs** section, add these Global Secure Access IPs and FQDN: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com, 150.171.19.0/24, 150.171.20.0/24, 13.107.232.0/24, 13.107.233.0/24, 150.171.15.0/24, 150.171.18.0/24, 151.206.0.0/16, 6.6.0.0/16`\n+6. Add these Microsoft 365 IP addresses (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+  `132.245.0.0/16, 204.79.197.215/32, 150.171.32.0/22, 131.253.33.215/32, 23.103.160.0/20, 40.96.0.0/13, 52.96.0.0/14, 40.104.0.0/15, 13.107.128.0/22, 13.107.18.10/31, 13.107.6.152/31, 52.238.78.88/32, 104.47.0.0/17, 52.100.0.0/14, 40.107.0.0/16, 40.92.0.0/15, 150.171.40.0/22, 52.104.0.0/14, 104.146.128.0/17, 40.108.128.0/17, 13.107.136.0/22, 40.126.0.0/18, 20.231.128.0/19, 20.190.128.0/18, 20.20.32.0/19`\n+7. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+---\n+\n+## Configuration scenarios\n+\n+### 1. Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Private Access forwarding profile.\n+1. Install a private network connector.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and private DNS.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **isn't** capturing traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access private applications via Global Secure Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    6. Validate the SMB file share traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and isn't shown in Cisco logs.\n+    7. Stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+### 2. Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Private Access forwarding profile.\n+1. Install a private network connector.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and private DNS.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Zero Trust Access and Umbrella modules.\n+1. Add private resources and create access policies.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **isn't** capturing traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access private applications via Global Secure Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Private Access (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate the SMB file share traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and isn't shown in Cisco logs.\n+    8. Validate the RDP traffic is captured in Cisco logs and isn't shown in Global Secure Access logs.\n+    9. Stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+ \n+### 3. Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Microsoft Access forwarding profile.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security, including other Microsoft IPs and FQDNs. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Zero Trust Access and Umbrella modules.\n+1. Add private resources and access policies.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **isn't** capturing traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourtenantdomain>.sharepoint.com`.\n+    6. Validate Global Secure Access traffic logs show these sites; Cisco Secure Access doesn't.\n+    7. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Private Access.\n+    8. Validate traffic logs in both portals.\n+    9. Stop collecting traffic and confirm Global Secure Access only captured Microsoft traffic.\n+\n+### 4. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Private Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+1. Add a custom bypass for Cisco Secure Access: `*.zpc.sse.cisco.com`.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security, including other Microsoft IPs and FQDNs.  For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Zero Trust Access module.\n+1. Add private resources and access policies.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For this scenario, Cisco Secure Access only handles private traffic. The Umbrella module is not installed.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **isn't** captured.\n+    5. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Private Access.\n+    6. Validate traffic logs in both portals.\n+    7. Stop collecting traffic and confirm Global Secure Access **didn't** handle private application traffic.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For troubleshooting health check failures, see [Troubleshoot the Global Secure Access client: Health check](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md).\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)\n+"
  },

    "sha": "33289b9aba475579de7c90137835af0a32bfdca8",
    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/how-to-cisco-vpn-coexistence.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 257,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 257,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-vpn-coexistence.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-vpn-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-vpn-coexistence.md?ref=de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,257 @@\n+---\n+title: Security Service Edge (SSE) Coexistence With Microsoft and Cisco VPNs\n+description: Microsoft and Cisco VPNs coexistence solution guide.\n+author: kenwith\n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: conceptual\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.subservice: entra-private-access\n+ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco VPNs\n+\n+Organizations require robust, unified solutions to ensure secure and seamless connectivity. Microsoft Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) capabilities that, when integrated with Cisco Virtual Private Networks (VPN), provide enhanced security and connectivity for diverse access scenarios.\n+\n+This guide outlines how to configure and deploy Microsoft Entra solutions alongside Cisco VPN offerings. By using both platforms, you can optimize your organization's security posture while maintaining high-performance connectivity for private applications, Microsoft 365 traffic, and internet access.\n+\n+## Cisco remote access VPN platforms\n+\n+This guide focuses on two Cisco remote access VPN platforms:\n+\n+- **[Cisco Secure Access VPN-as-a-Service (VPNaaS)](#cisco-secure-access-vpnaas)** \n+- **[Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Remote Access VPN](#cisco-asa-remote-access-vpn)**\n+\n+## Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - scenarios\n+1.  **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS for private access](#1-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-access-vpnaas-for-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS captures only private application traffic.\n+\n+2.  **[Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS](#2-microsoft-entra-private-access-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-access-vpn-for-private-access).**\n+Both clients handle traffic for separate private applications. Global Secure Access handles private applications in Microsoft Entra Private Access, while private applications hosted through Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS are accessed through Cisco Secure Client VPN. Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic.\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - prerequisites\n+\n+To configure Microsoft and Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS for a unified SASE solution:\n+\n+1. Set up Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Private Access. These products make up the Global Secure Access solution.\n+1. Establish connectivity to Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS.\n+1. Set up a Cisco remote access VPN profile.\n+1. Configure fully qualified domain name (FQDN) and IP bypasses (instructions below).\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. Enable and disable different traffic forwarding profiles for your Microsoft Entra tenant. For more information, see [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector. See [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+    > [!NOTE] \n+    > Private network connectors are required for Microsoft Entra Private Access applications.\n+1. Configure Quick Access to private resources and set up private Domain Name System (DNS) and DNS suffixes. See [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client on end-user devices. See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md). <a id=\"adding-a-custom-bypass\"></a>\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile custom bypass to exclude Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS service FQDN.\n+    1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center and browse to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+    2. Under Internet access policies, select **View**.\n+    3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+    4. Leave destination type as FQDN and enter the Cisco Secure Access VPN head end service domain, `*.vpn.sse.cisco.com` in Destination.\n+    5. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - Cisco Secure Access setup\n+\n+#### Split-Include configuration\n+\n+1. Configure the VPN profile Traffic Steering:\n+    1. From the Cisco Secure Access portal, go to **Connect > End User Connectivity > Virtual Private Network**.\n+    2. Select your VPN Profile, then **Traffic Steering**.\n+    3. In Tunnel Mode, select **Bypass Secure Access** and add exceptions (what to tunnel) for your private application subnets and the Global Secure Access synthetic IP range, `6.6.0.0/16`.\n+    4. In DNS Mode, select **Split DNS** and add the domain suffix of your private applications.\n+1. Install the Cisco Secure Client software.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Currently **Split-Include** is the only supported Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS configuration.\n+\n+## Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - configuration scenarios\n+\n+### 1. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS for private access\n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> A side-build of the Global Secure Access client for macOS is required for this specific scenario. Please contact support for more information.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile custom bypass to exclude Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS service. [Instructions above.](#adding-a-custom-bypass)\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Set up remote access VPN profile as [described previously](#split-include-configuration).\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client with VPN.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click **Global Secure Access Client** > **Advanced Diagnostics** > **Traffic tab** > **Start collecting**.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. In Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Global Secure Access > Monitor > Traffic logs**. Validate traffic is logged.\n+    5. In Cisco Secure Access portal, go to **Monitor > Activity Search**. Validate traffic to these websites **isn't** captured.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access traffic logs and present in Cisco Secure Access logs.\n+    8. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client and validate no private application traffic was captured.\n+\n+### 2. Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPN for private access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Private Access, and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install a private network connector for Microsoft Entra Private Access.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and set up Private DNS.\n+1. Create an app segment, for example an SMB file share. This will be the application you want to access through Global Secure Access and not Cisco VPN.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile [custom bypass](#adding-a-custom-bypass) to exclude Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS endpoint.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Set up remote access VPN profile as [described previously](#split-include-configuration).\n+1. Ensure that in step 1 you have configured applications to access through Cisco ASA VPN, for example an RDP server. This should be different apps than configured in Global Secure Access.\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client with VPN.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. Validate traffic in Microsoft Entra admin center traffic logs.\n+    5. Validate traffic **isn't** captured in Cisco Secure Access portal.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (e.g, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access logs and present in Cisco Secure Access logs.\n+    8. Access private application in Microsoft Entra Private Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    9. Validate SMB traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and not in Cisco Secure Access logs.\n+    10. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+\n+\n+## Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - scenarios\n+\n+1. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN for private access](#1-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-asa-remote-access-vpn-for-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco ASA captures only private application traffic.\n+\n+2. **[Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN](#2-microsoft-entra-private-access-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-asa-remote-access-vpn-for-private-access).**\n+Both clients handle traffic for separate private applications. Global Secure Access handles private applications in Microsoft Entra Private Access, while private applications hosted through Cisco ASA are accessed through Cisco Secure Client VPN. Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic.\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - prerequisites\n+\n+To configure Microsoft and Cisco ASA remote access VPN for a unified SASE solution:\n+\n+1. Set up Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Private Access. These products make up the Global Secure Access solution.\n+2. Establish remote access connectivity to your Cisco ASA.\n+3. Configure fully qualified domain name (FQDN) and IP bypasses (instructions below).\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. Enable and disable different traffic forwarding profiles for your Microsoft Entra tenant. For more information, see [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector. See [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+    > [!NOTE] \n+    > Private network connectors are required for Microsoft Entra Private Access applications.\n+1. Configure Quick Access to private resources and set up private Domain Name System (DNS) and DNS suffixes. See [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client on end-user devices. See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md).\n+<a id=\"adding-a-custom-bypass-for-cisco-asa\"></a>\n+\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile custom bypass to exclude Cisco ASA remote access VPN endpoint IP and FQDN.\n+    1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center and browse to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+    2. Under Internet access policies, select **View**.\n+    3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+    4. Leave destination type as FQDN and enter the FQDN used to connect to your Cisco ASA VPN in Destination.\n+    5. Set destination type as IP and enter the public IP address of your Cisco ASA.\n+    6. Select **Save**.\n+\n+## Cisco ASA VPN setup\n+\n+#### Split-Include configuration (ASA)\n+\n+Configure split-include for Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN:\n+\n+1. Sign in to Cisco ASA using the Cisco Adaptive Security Device Manager (ASDM) software.\n+2. Navigate to **Configuration > Remote Access VPN > Network (Client) Access > Secure Client Connection Profiles**.\n+3. Select an existing connection profile or create a new one, then select **Edit**.\n+4. Under **Group Policy**, specify the private IP address of the DNS server used for private traffic.\n+5. In the group policy settings, expand **Advanced > Split Tunneling** and configure the following:\n+  - **DNS Names**: `Inherit`\n+  - **Send All DNS Lookups Through Tunnel**: `No`\n+  - **Policy**: `Tunnel Network List Below`\n+  - **Network List**: Select the access list that includes your private application IP ranges.\n+6. Edit the access control list (ACL) to permit the private application IP ranges (for example, `10.101.0.0/16`) and the Global Secure Access synthetic IP range `6.6.0.0/16`.\n+7. Save and apply your changes.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Currently **Split-Include** is the only supported Cisco ASA VPN configuration.\n+\n+\n+## Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - configuration scenarios\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN\n+\n+#### 1. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN for private access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile [custom bypass](#adding-a-custom-bypass-for-cisco-asa) to exclude Cisco ASA remote access URL and public IP address.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure Cisco ASA remote access VPN connection profile for [split-include](#split-include-configuration-asa) configuration, as described previously.\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client or AnyConnect software.\n+1. Connect to your VPN endpoint.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. Validate traffic in Microsoft Entra admin center traffic logs.\n+    5. Validate website traffic **isn't** captured by your Cisco ASA.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access logs and present in Cisco logs.\n+    8. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+\n+#### 2. Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN for private access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Private Access, and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install a Private Network Connector for Microsoft Entra Private Access.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and set up Private DNS.\n+1. Create an app segment, for example an SMB file share. This will be the application you want to access through Global Secure Access and not Cisco ASA VPN.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile [custom bypass](#adding-a-custom-bypass-for-cisco-asa) to exclude Cisco ASA remote access URL and public IP address.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure Cisco ASA remote access VPN connection profile for [split-include](#split-include-configuration-asa) configuration, as described previously.\n+1. Ensure that in step 1 you have configured applications to access through Cisco ASA VPN, for example an RDP server. This should be different apps than configured in Global Secure Access.\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client software.\n+1. Connect to your VPN endpoint.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. Validate traffic in Microsoft Entra admin center traffic logs.\n+    5. Validate website traffic **isn't** captured by your Cisco ASA.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access logs and present in Cisco logs.\n+    8. Access private application in Microsoft Entra Private Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    9. Validate SMB traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and not in Cisco logs.\n+    10. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For troubleshooting health check failures, see [Troubleshoot the Global Secure Access client: Health check](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md).\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)"

This option to create self-service processes is useful, especially as organizations scale and hire more employees. Management capabilities include:\n+\n+- The ability to see active access package assignment of all of their direct reports.\n+- The ability to remove assignments for reports if the policy supports on behalf of requests.\n+\n+To manage your team assignments using the My Access portal, do the following steps:\n+\n+1. Sign in to the My Access portal at [https://myaccess.microsoft.com](https://myaccess.microsoft.com) as the direct manager of the team who you want to manage access package assignments for. Select an employee to see a list of their assignments.\n+\n+1. On the assignments page, you can see a list of their current access package assignments. You can also select **Remove access** to end that specific access package assignment for the user.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/entitlement-management-request-behalf/manage-team-reviews.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of managing team in the my access portal.\" lightbox=\"media/entitlement-management-request-behalf/manage-team-reviews.png\":::\n+\n ## Next steps\n \n - [Approve or deny access requests - entitlement management](entitlement-management-request-approve.md)"

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-risk-detection-types.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-risk-detection-types.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-risk-detection-types.md?ref=de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5",
    "patch": "@@ -16,7 +16,7 @@ ms.reviewer: cokoopma\n \n # Risk detection types and levels\n \n-Microsoft Entra ID Protection provides organizations with information about suspicious activity in their tenant and allows you to respond quickly to prevent further risk occurring. Risk detections are a powerful resource that can include any suspicious or anomalous activity related to user accounts and service principals in the directory. ID Protection risk detections can be linked to an individual user or sign-in event and contribute to the overall user risk score found in the [Risky users report](howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md#risky-users-report). \n+Microsoft Entra ID Protection provides organizations with information about suspicious activity in their tenant and allows you to respond quickly to prevent further risk occurring. Risk detections are a powerful resource that can include any suspicious or anomalous activity related to user accounts and service principals in the directory. ID Protection risk detections can be linked to an individual user or sign-in event and contribute to the overall user risk score found in the [Risky users report](concept-risk-reports.md). \n \n User risk detections might flag a legitimate user account as at risk, when a potential threat actor gains access to an account by compromising their credentials or when anomalous user activity is detected. Sign-in risk detections represent the probability that a given authentication request isn't the authorized owner of the account. Having the ability to identify risk at the user and sign-in level is critical for customers to be empowered to secure their tenant.\n "

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-risk-reports.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-risk-reports.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-protection%2Fconcept-risk-reports.md?ref=de99cbaa320ee4985627c53d775eaf29df73a2e5",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,120 @@\n+---\n+title: Reading the ID Protection Risk Reports\n+description: Learn how to access, filter, and use the Microsoft Entra ID Protection risk reports to mark users and sign-ins as risky or confirmed compromised.\n+\n+ms.service: entra-id-protection\n+\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+\n+author: shlipsey3\n+ms.author: sarahlipsey\n+manager: pmwongera \n+ms.reviewer: chuqiaoshi\n+---\n+# Microsoft Entra ID Protection risk reports\n+\n+Microsoft Entra ID Protection helps protect your organization by automatically detecting and responding to identity-based risks. While automated remediation handles many threats, some situations require manual investigation and action. The ID Protection risk reports provide the insights you need to identify, investigate, and respond to potential security threats affecting your users, sign-ins, and workload identities.\n+\n+## Access the risk reports\n+\n+The [ID Protection Dashboard](id-protection-dashboard.md) provides a summary of important insights that you can use at any time to identify potential risks.\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Security Reader](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-reader).\n+1. Browse to **ID Protection** > **Dashboard**.\n+1. Select a report from the ID Protection navigation menu.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-risk-reports/dashboard.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Microsoft Entra ID Protection dashboard.\" lightbox=\"media/concept-risk-reports/dashboard-expanded.png\":::\n+\n+\n+Each report launches with a list of all detections for the period shown at the top of the report. You can filter and add or remove columns based on your preference. Download the data in .CSV or .JSON format for further processing. To integrate the reports with Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools for further analysis, see [Configure diagnostic settings](../identity/monitoring-health/howto-configure-diagnostic-settings.md).\n+\n+## View details and take action\n+\n+Select an entry in a report to view more details, which differ based on the report you're viewing. From the details pane you can also take action on the selected user or sign-in. You can select one or multiple entries and either confirm the risk or dismiss it. You can also start a password reset flow from the user. These capabilities have different role requirements, so if an option is greyed out, you need a higher privileged role. For more information, see [ID Protection required roles](overview-identity-protection.md#required-roles).\n+\n+### Risky users\n+\n+The details of a selected risky user provide information on the risk that was remediated, dismissed, or is still currently at risk and needs investigation. You're also provided details about the associated risk detections.\n+\n+A user becomes a risky user when:\n+\n+- They have one or more risky sign-ins.\n+- They have one or more [risks](concept-identity-protection-risks.md) detected on their account, like leaked credentials.\n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> If you have Security Copilot, you have access to a **[summary in natural language](../security-copilot/entra-risky-user-summarization.md)** including: why the user risk level was elevated, guidance on how to mitigate and respond, and links to other helpful items or documentation.\n+\n+From the **Risky users report**, select a user to view more details about their risk events and even take action on that user.\n+\n+**Risky users details** include:\n+- User ID\n+- Recent risky sign-ins\n+- Detections not linked to a sign-in\n+- Risk history\n+\n+The **Risk history tab** shows the events that led to a user risk change in the last 90 days. This list includes risk detections that increased the user's risk. It can also include user or admin remediation actions that lowered the user's risk; for example, a user resetting their password or an admin dismissing the risk.\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [id-protection-admin-action-user](../includes/id-protection-admin-action-user.md)]\n+\n+### Risky sign-ins\n+\n+The Risky sign-ins report lists sign-ins that are at risk, confirmed compromised, confirmed safe, dismissed, or remediated. The details pane provides more information about the sign-in attempt that might help during an investigation, such as real-time and aggregate risk levels associated with sign-in attempts and the detection types triggered.\n+\n+**Risky sign-ins details** include:\n+- The application the user was trying to access\n+- Conditional Access policies applied\n+- MFA details\n+- Device, application, and location information\n+- Risk state, risk level, and the source of the risk detection (ID Protection or Microsoft Defender for Endpoint)\n+\n+The **Risky sign-ins report** contains filterable data for up to the past 30 days (one month). ID Protection evaluates risk for all authentication flows, whether it's interactive or non-interactive. The Risky sign-ins report shows both interactive and non-interactive sign-ins. To modify this view, use the \"sign-in type\" filter.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-risk-reports/risky-sign-ins-report.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Risky sign-ins report.\" lightbox=\"media/concept-risk-reports/risky-sign-ins-report.png\":::\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [id-protection-admin-action-sign-in](../includes/id-protection-admin-action-sign-in.md)]\n+\n+To learn more about when to take each of these actions, see [How does Microsoft use my risk feedback](howto-identity-protection-risk-feedback.md#how-does-microsoft-use-my-risk-feedback)\n+\n+### Risky Workload IDs\n+\n+A [workload identity](../workload-id/workload-identities-overview.md) is an identity that allows an application access to resources, sometimes in the context of a user. From the Risky Workload ID details page you can access service principal sign-in and audit logs for further analysis.\n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> Full risk details and risk-based access controls are available to Workload Identities Premium customers; however, customers without a **[Workload Identities Premium](../workload-id/workload-identities-faqs.md)** license still receive all detections with limited reporting details.\n+\n+**Risky Workload IDs details** include:\n+- Service principal ID\n+- Risk state and risk level\n+- Risk history\n+\n+### Risk detections\n+\n+The Risk detections report provides insights into the various risk detections associated with users and sign-ins. The details include information about the type of risk detected, the user, or sign-in it pertains to, and the current status of the risk. From the details pane you can also access the associated user risk report, the user's sign-ins, and risk detections.\n+\n+**Risk detections details** include:\n+- Detection type\n+- Risk state, risk level, and risk detail\n+- Attack type\n+- Source of the risk detection (ID Protection or Microsoft Defender for Endpoint)\n+\n+The Risk detections report contains filterable data for up to the past 90 days (three months).\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/concept-risk-reports/risk-detections-report.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Risk detections report.\" lightbox=\"media/concept-risk-reports/risk-detections-report.png\":::\n+\n+With the information provided by the Risk detections report, administrators can find:\n+\n+- Information about each risk detection\n+- Attack type based on MITRE ATT&CK framework\n+- Other risks triggered at the same time\n+- Sign-in attempt location\n+- Link out to more detail from Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps.\n+\n+Administrators can then choose to return to the user's risk or sign-ins report to take actions based on information gathered.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Our system might detect that:\n+> - the risk event that contributed to the user risk score was a false positive; or\n+> - the user risk was remediated with policy enforcement, such as completing an MFA prompt or secure password change.\n+>\n+> Therefore, our system dismisses the risk state and a risk detail of \"AI confirmed sign-in safe\" surfaces and no longer contributes to the user's risk."
  },

    "sha": "dde0be42d5e20a751f0eed02f8dcb30353bcaac9",
    "filename": "docs/id-protection/howto-identity-protection-investigate-risk.md",
