    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-secure-access-coexistence.md?ref=eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,239 @@\n+---\n+title: Security Service Edge (SSE) Coexistence With Microsoft and Cisco Secure Access\n+description: Microsoft and Cisco’s Secure Access coexistence solution guide.\n+author: kenwith\n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: conceptual\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.subservice: entra-private-access \n+ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco Secure Access\n+\n+Learn how to configure Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence using Global Secure Access and Cisco Secure Access.\n+\n+In today's digital landscape, organizations need robust, unified solutions for secure and seamless connectivity. Global Secure Access and Cisco Secure Access offer complementary Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) capabilities. When integrated, these platforms enhance security and connectivity for diverse access scenarios.\n+\n+This guide outlines how to configure and deploy Global Secure Access solutions alongside Cisco Secure Access SSE offerings. By using both platforms, you can optimize your organization's security posture while maintaining high-performance connectivity for private applications, Microsoft 365 traffic, and internet access.\n+\n+## Scenarios\n+\n+This guide covers the following coexistence scenarios:\n+\n+1.  **[Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access](#1-microsoft-entra-private-access-with-cisco-secure-internet-access).**\n+In this scenario, Global Secure Access handles private application traffic. Cisco Secure Internet Access provides DNS security and SWG capabilities.\n+\n+2.  **[Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access](#2-microsoft-entra-private-access-with-cisco-secure-internet-access-and-cisco-secure-private-access).**\n+In this scenario, both clients handle traffic for separate private applications. Global Secure Access handles private applications in Microsoft Entra Private Access, while the Cisco Secure Client - Zero Trust Access module handles private applications in Cisco Secure Private Access. Web and DNS traffic is protected by Cisco Secure Internet Access.\n+\n+3.  **[Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access](#3-microsoft-entra-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-internet-access-and-cisco-secure-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access manages all Microsoft 365 traffic. The Cisco Secure Client - Zero Trust Access module handles private applications in Cisco Secure Private Access. Web and DNS traffic is protected by Cisco Secure Internet Access.\n+\n+4.  **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Private Access](#4-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access manages internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco Secure Access handles only Private Access with the Cisco Secure Client - Zero Trust Access module.\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+To configure Global Secure Access and Cisco Secure Access for a unified SASE solution:\n+\n+- Set up Global Secure Access (Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Private Access).\n+- Configure Cisco Secure Internet Access and Secure Private Access.\n+- Establish required FQDN and IP bypasses for integration between the platforms.\n+\n+## Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. **Enable and disable different traffic forwarding profiles** for your Microsoft Entra tenant. See [Traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+1. **Install and configure the private network connector** for Private Access applications. See [Configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+1. **Configure Quick Access** to private resources and set up private DNS and DNS suffixes. See [Configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+1. **Install and configure the Global Secure Access client** on end-user devices. See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md).\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Private Network Connectors are required for Private Access applications.\n+\n+## Cisco Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. **Set up a resource connector** for private applications. See Cisco documentation for [managing resource connectors and connector groups](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-resource-connectors-and-connector-groups).\n+1. **Provision users and groups**. Integration with Microsoft Entra ID provides the best user experience. See Cisco documentation for [Microsoft Entra ID SAML configuration](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/configure-azure-for-saml).\n+1. **Add private resources and create access policies**. See Cisco documentation for [managing private access rules](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-private-access-rules).\n+1. **Set up internet security and configure bypasses** for coexistence. See Cisco documentation for [managing internet security](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manage-internet-security).\n+1. **Install and configure the Cisco Secure Client**. See Cisco documentation for [downloading and installing the client for Windows and macOS](https://docs.sse.cisco.com/sse-user-guide/docs/manual-installation-of-cisco-secure-client-windows-and-macos).\n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> Cisco released a Cisco Secure Client (CSC) feature to improve coexistence with Global Secure Access. These steps need to be performed after the initial installation, or re-installation (not required to run again when upgrading), of CSC version 5.1.10.x (or later).\n+> 1. Install Cisco Secure Client version 5.1.10.x.\n+> 1. Open CMD prompt as an administrator and run these commands:\n+> 1. `\"%ProgramFiles(x86)%\\Cisco\\Cisco Secure Client\\acsocktool.exe\" -slwm 10`\n+> 1. `net stop csc_vpnagent && net stop acsock && net start csc_vpnagent`\n+\n+## Bypass configuration for coexistence\n+\n+### Bypass Cisco Secure Access/Umbrella required IPs and FQDN in Global Secure Access\n+\n+1. In the Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+2. Under **Internet access policies**, select **View**.\n+3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+4. Enter the following IPs:\n+    `208.67.222.222, 208.67.220.220, 67.215.64.0/19, 146.112.0.0/16, 155.190.0.0/16, 185.60.84.0/22, 204.194.232.0/21, 208.67.216.0/21, 208.69.32.0/21`\n+5. Add a rule for the destination: `*.zpc.sse.cisco.com`\n+6. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access/Umbrella\n+\n+#### [Cisco Secure Access Portal](#tab/cisco-secure-access-portal)\n+\n+1. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, go to **Connect > End User Connectivity > Internet Security**.\n+2. In the **Traffic Steering** section, select **Add Destination > Bypass Secure Access**, add the following FQDN, and save: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Secure Access has an implied wildcard, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+3. Add these Microsoft 365 FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+4. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+5. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+6. In the Traffic Steering section, select **Add Destination > Bypass web proxy only**, add these IPs, and save: `150.171.19.0/24, 150.171.20.0/24, 13.107.232.0/24, 13.107.233.0/24, 150.171.15.0/24, 150.171.18.0/24, 151.206.0.0/16, 6.6.0.0/16`\n+7. Add these Microsoft 365 IP addresses (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `132.245.0.0/16, 204.79.197.215/32, 150.171.32.0/22, 131.253.33.215/32, 23.103.160.0/20, 40.96.0.0/13, 52.96.0.0/14, 40.104.0.0/15, 13.107.128.0/22, 13.107.18.10/31, 13.107.6.152/31, 52.238.78.88/32, 104.47.0.0/17, 52.100.0.0/14, 40.107.0.0/16, 40.92.0.0/15, 150.171.40.0/22, 52.104.0.0/14, 104.146.128.0/17, 40.108.128.0/17, 13.107.136.0/22, 40.126.0.0/18, 20.231.128.0/19, 20.190.128.0/18, 20.20.32.0/19`\n+8. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+#### [Cisco Umbrella Portal](#tab/cisco-umbrella-portal)\n+\n+1. Add domain suffixes and Microsoft Entra service FQDNs to the **Internal domains** list: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Cisco Umbrella supports implied wildcards, so you can use `globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com`.\n+2. Add these Microsoft 365 FQDNs (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+    `auth.microsoft.com, msftidentity.com, msidentity.com, onmicrosoft.com, outlook.com, protection.outlook.com, sharepoint.com, sharepointonline.com, svc.ms, wns.windows.com, account.activedirectory.windowsazure.com, accounts.accesscontrol.windows.net, admin.onedrive.com, adminwebservice.microsoftonline.com, api.passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, autologon.microsoftazuread-sso.com, becws.microsoftonline.com, ccs.login.microsoftonline.com, clientconfig.microsoftonline-p.net, companymanager.microsoftonline.com, device.login.microsoftonline.com, g.live.com, graph.microsoft.com, graph.windows.net, login-us.microsoftonline.com, login.microsoft.com, login.microsoftonline-p.com, login.microsoftonline.com, login.windows.net, logincert.microsoftonline.com, loginex.microsoftonline.com, nexus.microsoftonline-p.com, officeclient.microsoft.com, oneclient.sfx.ms, outlook.cloud.microsoft, outlook.office.com, outlook.office365.com, passwordreset.microsoftonline.com, provisioningapi.microsoftonline.com, spoprod-a.akamaihd.net`\n+3. Add the Quick Access FQDN (only required if you use Private Access with Quick Access). `<quickaccessapplicationid>.globalsecureaccess.local`   \n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > Replace `<quickaccessapplicationid>` with the application ID of your Quick Access app.\n+4. Add DNS suffixes defined in your Private DNS or Enterprise App segments (only required if Private Access traffic forwarding profile is enabled). For example, if your Private DNS suffix is `contoso.local` and you have a private app at `contoso.com`, add both suffixes.\n+5. In the **External Domains & IPs** section, add these Global Secure Access IPs and FQDN: `*.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com, 150.171.19.0/24, 150.171.20.0/24, 13.107.232.0/24, 13.107.233.0/24, 150.171.15.0/24, 150.171.18.0/24, 151.206.0.0/16, 6.6.0.0/16`\n+6. Add these Microsoft 365 IP addresses (only required if Microsoft traffic forwarding profile is enabled):\n+  `132.245.0.0/16, 204.79.197.215/32, 150.171.32.0/22, 131.253.33.215/32, 23.103.160.0/20, 40.96.0.0/13, 52.96.0.0/14, 40.104.0.0/15, 13.107.128.0/22, 13.107.18.10/31, 13.107.6.152/31, 52.238.78.88/32, 104.47.0.0/17, 52.100.0.0/14, 40.107.0.0/16, 40.92.0.0/15, 150.171.40.0/22, 52.104.0.0/14, 104.146.128.0/17, 40.108.128.0/17, 13.107.136.0/22, 40.126.0.0/18, 20.231.128.0/19, 20.190.128.0/18, 20.20.32.0/19`\n+7. Restart Cisco Umbrella client services or restart the machine where the clients are installed.\n+\n+---\n+\n+## Configuration scenarios\n+\n+### 1. Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Private Access forwarding profile.\n+1. Install a private network connector.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and private DNS.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Umbrella module.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **isn't** capturing traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access private applications via Global Secure Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    6. Validate the SMB file share traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and isn't shown in Cisco logs.\n+    7. Stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+\n+### 2. Microsoft Entra Private Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Private Access forwarding profile.\n+1. Install a private network connector.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and private DNS.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Zero Trust Access and Umbrella modules.\n+1. Add private resources and create access policies.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click Global Secure Access Client > Advanced Diagnostics > Traffic tab > Start collecting.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **isn't** capturing traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access private applications via Global Secure Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Private Access (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate the SMB file share traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and isn't shown in Cisco logs.\n+    8. Validate the RDP traffic is captured in Cisco logs and isn't shown in Global Secure Access logs.\n+    9. Stop collecting traffic and confirm correct traffic handling.\n+ \n+### 3. Microsoft Entra Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Internet Access and Cisco Secure Private Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Microsoft Access forwarding profile.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security, including other Microsoft IPs and FQDNs. For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Zero Trust Access and Umbrella modules.\n+1. Add private resources and access policies.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled and the Umbrella profile is `Active`.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com` in browsers.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client **isn't** capturing traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **is** captured.\n+    5. Access `outlook.office365.com`, `<yourtenantdomain>.sharepoint.com`.\n+    6. Validate Global Secure Access traffic logs show these sites; Cisco Secure Access doesn't.\n+    7. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Private Access.\n+    8. Validate traffic logs in both portals.\n+    9. Stop collecting traffic and confirm Global Secure Access only captured Microsoft traffic.\n+\n+### 4. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Private Access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Enable Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+1. Add a custom bypass for Cisco Secure Access: `*.zpc.sse.cisco.com`.\n+\n+**Cisco Secure Access configuration**\n+\n+1. Configure required destinations to bypass Internet Security, including other Microsoft IPs and FQDNs.  For instructions, see [Bypass Global Secure Access IPs and FQDNs in Cisco Secure Access / Umbrella](#bypass-global-secure-access-ips-and-fqdns-in-cisco-secure-accessumbrella) and select the tab for **Cisco Secure Access portal** or **Umbrella portal**.\n+1. Deploy and configure Cisco Secure Client with Zero Trust Access module.\n+1. Add private resources and access policies.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For this scenario, Cisco Secure Access only handles private traffic. The Umbrella module is not installed.\n+\n+**Validation**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic for these sites.\n+    4. In the Cisco Secure Access portal, validate traffic to these sites **isn't** captured.\n+    5. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Private Access.\n+    6. Validate traffic logs in both portals.\n+    7. Stop collecting traffic and confirm Global Secure Access **didn't** handle private application traffic.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For troubleshooting health check failures, see [Troubleshoot the Global Secure Access client: Health check](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md).\n+\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)\n+"

    "sha": "33289b9aba475579de7c90137835af0a32bfdca8",

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-vpn-coexistence.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-vpn-coexistence.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-cisco-vpn-coexistence.md?ref=eeebdfd03a4004aa9092dc0d6192b6bb8a51cbda",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,257 @@\n+---\n+title: Security Service Edge (SSE) Coexistence With Microsoft and Cisco VPNs\n+description: Microsoft and Cisco VPNs coexistence solution guide.\n+author: kenwith\n+ms.author: kenwith\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.topic: conceptual\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.subservice: entra-private-access\n+ms.reviewer: shkhalid\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+---\n+\n+# Security Service Edge (SSE) coexistence with Microsoft and Cisco VPNs\n+\n+Organizations require robust, unified solutions to ensure secure and seamless connectivity. Microsoft Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) capabilities that, when integrated with Cisco Virtual Private Networks (VPN), provide enhanced security and connectivity for diverse access scenarios.\n+\n+This guide outlines how to configure and deploy Microsoft Entra solutions alongside Cisco VPN offerings. By using both platforms, you can optimize your organization's security posture while maintaining high-performance connectivity for private applications, Microsoft 365 traffic, and internet access.\n+\n+## Cisco remote access VPN platforms\n+\n+This guide focuses on two Cisco remote access VPN platforms:\n+\n+- **[Cisco Secure Access VPN-as-a-Service (VPNaaS)](#cisco-secure-access-vpnaas)** \n+- **[Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Remote Access VPN](#cisco-asa-remote-access-vpn)**\n+\n+## Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - scenarios\n+1.  **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS for private access](#1-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-access-vpnaas-for-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS captures only private application traffic.\n+\n+2.  **[Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS](#2-microsoft-entra-private-access-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-secure-access-vpn-for-private-access).**\n+Both clients handle traffic for separate private applications. Global Secure Access handles private applications in Microsoft Entra Private Access, while private applications hosted through Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS are accessed through Cisco Secure Client VPN. Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic.\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - prerequisites\n+\n+To configure Microsoft and Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS for a unified SASE solution:\n+\n+1. Set up Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Private Access. These products make up the Global Secure Access solution.\n+1. Establish connectivity to Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS.\n+1. Set up a Cisco remote access VPN profile.\n+1. Configure fully qualified domain name (FQDN) and IP bypasses (instructions below).\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. Enable and disable different traffic forwarding profiles for your Microsoft Entra tenant. For more information, see [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector. See [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+    > [!NOTE] \n+    > Private network connectors are required for Microsoft Entra Private Access applications.\n+1. Configure Quick Access to private resources and set up private Domain Name System (DNS) and DNS suffixes. See [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client on end-user devices. See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md). <a id=\"adding-a-custom-bypass\"></a>\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile custom bypass to exclude Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS service FQDN.\n+    1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center and browse to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+    2. Under Internet access policies, select **View**.\n+    3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+    4. Leave destination type as FQDN and enter the Cisco Secure Access VPN head end service domain, `*.vpn.sse.cisco.com` in Destination.\n+    5. Select **Save**.\n+\n+### Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - Cisco Secure Access setup\n+\n+#### Split-Include configuration\n+\n+1. Configure the VPN profile Traffic Steering:\n+    1. From the Cisco Secure Access portal, go to **Connect > End User Connectivity > Virtual Private Network**.\n+    2. Select your VPN Profile, then **Traffic Steering**.\n+    3. In Tunnel Mode, select **Bypass Secure Access** and add exceptions (what to tunnel) for your private application subnets and the Global Secure Access synthetic IP range, `6.6.0.0/16`.\n+    4. In DNS Mode, select **Split DNS** and add the domain suffix of your private applications.\n+1. Install the Cisco Secure Client software.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Currently **Split-Include** is the only supported Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS configuration.\n+\n+## Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS - configuration scenarios\n+\n+### 1. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS for private access\n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> A side-build of the Global Secure Access client for macOS is required for this specific scenario. Please contact support for more information.\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile custom bypass to exclude Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS service. [Instructions above.](#adding-a-custom-bypass)\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Set up remote access VPN profile as [described previously](#split-include-configuration).\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client with VPN.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. In the system tray, right-click **Global Secure Access Client** > **Advanced Diagnostics** > **Traffic tab** > **Start collecting**.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. In Microsoft Entra admin center, go to **Global Secure Access > Monitor > Traffic logs**. Validate traffic is logged.\n+    5. In Cisco Secure Access portal, go to **Monitor > Activity Search**. Validate traffic to these websites **isn't** captured.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access traffic logs and present in Cisco Secure Access logs.\n+    8. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client and validate no private application traffic was captured.\n+\n+### 2. Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco Secure Access VPN for private access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Private Access, and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install a private network connector for Microsoft Entra Private Access.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and set up Private DNS.\n+1. Create an app segment, for example an SMB file share. This will be the application you want to access through Global Secure Access and not Cisco VPN.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile [custom bypass](#adding-a-custom-bypass) to exclude Cisco Secure Access VPNaaS endpoint.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Set up remote access VPN profile as [described previously](#split-include-configuration).\n+1. Ensure that in step 1 you have configured applications to access through Cisco ASA VPN, for example an RDP server. This should be different apps than configured in Global Secure Access.\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client with VPN.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. Validate traffic in Microsoft Entra admin center traffic logs.\n+    5. Validate traffic **isn't** captured in Cisco Secure Access portal.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (e.g, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access logs and present in Cisco Secure Access logs.\n+    8. Access private application in Microsoft Entra Private Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    9. Validate SMB traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and not in Cisco Secure Access logs.\n+    10. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+\n+\n+## Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - scenarios\n+\n+1. **[Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN for private access](#1-microsoft-entra-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-asa-remote-access-vpn-for-private-access).**\n+Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic. Cisco ASA captures only private application traffic.\n+\n+2. **[Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN](#2-microsoft-entra-private-access-internet-access-and-microsoft-access-with-cisco-asa-remote-access-vpn-for-private-access).**\n+Both clients handle traffic for separate private applications. Global Secure Access handles private applications in Microsoft Entra Private Access, while private applications hosted through Cisco ASA are accessed through Cisco Secure Client VPN. Global Secure Access handles internet and Microsoft traffic.\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - prerequisites\n+\n+To configure Microsoft and Cisco ASA remote access VPN for a unified SASE solution:\n+\n+1. Set up Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Entra Private Access. These products make up the Global Secure Access solution.\n+2. Establish remote access connectivity to your Cisco ASA.\n+3. Configure fully qualified domain name (FQDN) and IP bypasses (instructions below).\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - Global Secure Access setup\n+\n+1. Enable and disable different traffic forwarding profiles for your Microsoft Entra tenant. For more information, see [Global Secure Access traffic forwarding profiles](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Microsoft Entra private network connector. See [How to configure connectors](how-to-configure-connectors.md).\n+    > [!NOTE] \n+    > Private network connectors are required for Microsoft Entra Private Access applications.\n+1. Configure Quick Access to private resources and set up private Domain Name System (DNS) and DNS suffixes. See [How to configure Quick Access](how-to-configure-quick-access.md).\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client on end-user devices. See [Global Secure Access clients](concept-clients.md).\n+<a id=\"adding-a-custom-bypass-for-cisco-asa\"></a>\n+\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile custom bypass to exclude Cisco ASA remote access VPN endpoint IP and FQDN.\n+    1. Sign in to Microsoft Entra admin center and browse to **Global Secure Access > Connect > Traffic forwarding > Internet access profile**.\n+    2. Under Internet access policies, select **View**.\n+    3. Expand **Custom Bypass** and select **Add rule**.\n+    4. Leave destination type as FQDN and enter the FQDN used to connect to your Cisco ASA VPN in Destination.\n+    5. Set destination type as IP and enter the public IP address of your Cisco ASA.\n+    6. Select **Save**.\n+\n+## Cisco ASA VPN setup\n+\n+#### Split-Include configuration (ASA)\n+\n+Configure split-include for Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN:\n+\n+1. Sign in to Cisco ASA using the Cisco Adaptive Security Device Manager (ASDM) software.\n+2. Navigate to **Configuration > Remote Access VPN > Network (Client) Access > Secure Client Connection Profiles**.\n+3. Select an existing connection profile or create a new one, then select **Edit**.\n+4. Under **Group Policy**, specify the private IP address of the DNS server used for private traffic.\n+5. In the group policy settings, expand **Advanced > Split Tunneling** and configure the following:\n+  - **DNS Names**: `Inherit`\n+  - **Send All DNS Lookups Through Tunnel**: `No`\n+  - **Policy**: `Tunnel Network List Below`\n+  - **Network List**: Select the access list that includes your private application IP ranges.\n+6. Edit the access control list (ACL) to permit the private application IP ranges (for example, `10.101.0.0/16`) and the Global Secure Access synthetic IP range `6.6.0.0/16`.\n+7. Save and apply your changes.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Currently **Split-Include** is the only supported Cisco ASA VPN configuration.\n+\n+\n+## Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN - configuration scenarios\n+\n+### Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN\n+\n+#### 1. Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN for private access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile [custom bypass](#adding-a-custom-bypass-for-cisco-asa) to exclude Cisco ASA remote access URL and public IP address.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure Cisco ASA remote access VPN connection profile for [split-include](#split-include-configuration-asa) configuration, as described previously.\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client or AnyConnect software.\n+1. Connect to your VPN endpoint.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. Validate traffic in Microsoft Entra admin center traffic logs.\n+    5. Validate website traffic **isn't** captured by your Cisco ASA.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access logs and present in Cisco logs.\n+    8. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+\n+#### 2. Microsoft Entra Private Access, Internet Access, and Microsoft Access with Cisco ASA Remote Access VPN for private access\n+\n+**Global Secure Access configuration:**\n+1. Enable Microsoft Entra Internet Access, Private Access, and Microsoft Access forwarding profiles.\n+1. Install a Private Network Connector for Microsoft Entra Private Access.\n+1. Configure Quick Access and set up Private DNS.\n+1. Create an app segment, for example an SMB file share. This will be the application you want to access through Global Secure Access and not Cisco ASA VPN.\n+1. Add an Internet Access traffic forwarding profile [custom bypass](#adding-a-custom-bypass-for-cisco-asa) to exclude Cisco ASA remote access URL and public IP address.\n+1. Install and configure the Global Secure Access client for Windows or macOS.\n+\n+**Cisco configuration:**\n+1. Configure Cisco ASA remote access VPN connection profile for [split-include](#split-include-configuration-asa) configuration, as described previously.\n+1. Ensure that in step 1 you have configured applications to access through Cisco ASA VPN, for example an RDP server. This should be different apps than configured in Global Secure Access.\n+1. Install Cisco Secure Client software.\n+1. Connect to your VPN endpoint.\n+\n+**Validation:**\n+1. Ensure both clients are enabled.\n+1. To verify rules are applied and health checks pass, use Advanced Diagnostics in the Global Secure Access client.\n+1. Test traffic flow by accessing various sites and validating traffic logs in both platforms.\n+    1. Start collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+    2. Access websites: `bing.com`, `salesforce.com`, `outlook.office365.com`.\n+    3. Verify Global Secure Access client captures traffic from these sites.\n+    4. Validate traffic in Microsoft Entra admin center traffic logs.\n+    5. Validate website traffic **isn't** captured by your Cisco ASA.\n+    6. Access private resources via Cisco Secure Client (for example, RDP session).\n+    7. Validate RDP traffic is missing from Global Secure Access logs and present in Cisco logs.\n+    8. Access private application in Microsoft Entra Private Access (for example, SMB file share).\n+    9. Validate SMB traffic is captured in Global Secure Access logs and not in Cisco logs.\n+    10. Stop collecting traffic in Global Secure Access client.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> For troubleshooting health check failures, see [Troubleshoot the Global Secure Access client: Health check](troubleshoot-global-secure-access-client-diagnostics-health-check.md).\n+## Next steps\n+\n+- [What is Global Secure Access?](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md)"

ai_summary.Messages:
{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "a12420fe6091c9d24ed8f23582b83ec7041b48f2",
    "filename": "docs/external-id/customers/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 160,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 160,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/79a68f0640749a00ade2615a8f5ab891343b293a/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcustomers%2Fhow-to-integrate-fraud-protection.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/79a68f0640749a00ade2615a8f5ab891343b293a/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcustomers%2Fhow-to-integrate-fraud-protection.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Fcustomers%2Fhow-to-integrate-fraud-protection.md?ref=79a68f0640749a00ade2615a8f5ab891343b293a",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,160 @@\n+---\n+title: Fraud Protection Integration\n+description: Learn how to configure Arkose Labs and Human fraud protection with Microsoft Entra External ID to block bot attacks and fake account creation during user sign-up flows.\n+author: csmulligan\n+ms.author: cmulligan\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.service: entra-external-id\n+ms.subservice: external\n+zone_pivot_groups: fraud-protection-integration\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 09/24/2025\n+#Customer intent: As an IT admin, I want to integrate Arkose Labs and Human with Microsoft Entra External ID to prevent fake account sign-ups and bot attacks using the Microsoft Entra admin center.\n+---\n+# Integrate Microsoft Entra External ID with Arkose Labs and Human for fraud protection (preview)\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [applies-to-external-only](../includes/applies-to-external-only.md)]\n+\n+Microsoft Entra External ID supports integration with third-party fraud protection providers, such as [Arkose Labs](https://www.arkoselabs.com/solutions/fake-account-creation/) and [HUMAN](https://www.humansecurity.com/), to help prevent fake account sign-ups and bot attacks. These providers offer comprehensive fraud protection solutions that enable organizations to detect and block automated attacks, such as bot-driven registrations, during the user sign-up process.  \n+\n+By integrating Arkose Labs, HUMAN, or both with Microsoft Entra External ID, you can leverage their advanced risk assessment capabilities to ensure that only legitimate users create accounts.  \n+\n+This article explains how to integrate fraud protection providers with Microsoft Entra External ID.\n+\n+::: zone pivot=\"arkose\"\n+\n+## How Arkose Labs works\n+\n+When a user attempts to sign up, the Arkose Labs service evaluates the request and determines if it's likely to be fraudulent. If the request is flagged as suspicious, the user is presented with a challenge (like a CAPTCHA) to verify that they're human. If the user successfully completes the challenge, they can proceed with the sign-up process. Once this feature is enabled, you'll be able to view Arkose challenge metrics in the Arkose Labs dashboard. Additionally, you can fine-tune risk policies by coordinating with Arkose Labs support.\n+\n+You can complete the integration in both the Microsoft Entra admin center and the Microsoft Graph API. This article provides instructions for the Microsoft Entra admin center.\n+\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+- An [external tenant](how-to-create-external-tenant-portal.md).\n+- A [registered application](/entra/identity-platform/quickstart-register-app) in the tenant.\n+- An account with at least an [Authentication Extensibility Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#authentication-extensibility-administrator) or [Application Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#application-administrator) role in the external tenant.\n+- An Arkose Labs account. Go to arkoselabs.com to [request a demo](https://www.arkoselabs.com/bot-management-demo/)\n+- The following configuration values from Arkose:\n+    - Public key (GUID format).\n+    - Private key (GUID format).\n+    - Client subdomain: use only the subdomain prefix (for example, \"client-api\"), not the full domain. \n+    - Verify subdomain: use only the subdomain prefix (for example, \"verify-api\"), not the full domain.\n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> [![Try it now](./media/common/try-it-now.png)](https://woodgrovedemo.com/#usecase=ArkoseFraudProtection)\n+> To try out this feature, go to the Woodgrove Groceries demo and start the 'Arkose fraud protection' use case.\n+\n+## Configure Arkose Labs in the Microsoft Entra admin center\n+\n+To integrate Arkose Labs with Microsoft Entra External ID, you can use the Service Integration wizard in Microsoft Entra admin center to create a fraud protection provider policy.  \n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least an [Authentication Extensibility Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#authentication-extensibility-administrator) or [Application Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#application-administrator).\n+1. If you have access to multiple tenants, use the **Settings** icon :::image type=\"icon\" source=\"media/common/admin-center-settings-icon.png\" border=\"false\"::: in the top menu to switch to the external tenant from the **Directories + subscriptions** menu.\n+1. Browse to **Home** > **Service Integrations** > **Sign-up protection (Preview)** to start the wizard.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/configure-sign-up-protection.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Sign-up protection (Preview) page.\":::\n+\n+1. Enter a name for the policy, such as *ArkosePolicy*.\n+1. Select the scenarios to apply the fraud protection policy to and select **Next**.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/policy-set-up.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing setting up a protection policy.\":::\n+\n+1. In the **Choose a fraud protection provider for sign-up** step, select **Arkose Labs** as the provider and select **Next**.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/choose-fraud-protection-provider.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing selecting the Arkose Labs fraud protection provider.\":::\n+\n+1. In the **Configure Arkose Labs for sign-up protection** step, select the **Create new** configuration, and enter the configuration values you received from Arkose Labs:\n+    - **Public key**: Enter the public key (GUID format).\n+    - **Private key**: Enter the private key (GUID format).\n+    - **Client subdomain**: Enter only the subdomain prefix (for example, \"client-api\"), not the full domain.\n+    - **Verify subdomain**: Enter only the subdomain prefix (for example, \"verify-api\"), not the full domain.\n+\n+1. Or select an existing configuration if you have already set one up and select **Next**.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/provider-configuration.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing configuring the Arkose Labs provider.\":::\n+\n+1. Select the app you want to protect with Arkose Labs fraud protection. You can select one or more applications that you have registered in your external tenant.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/select-apps-to-protect.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing selecting an application to protect.\":::\n+\n+1. Review the configuration and select **Create policy** to create the fraud protection policy.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/create-policy.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing creating a policy for Arkose Labs.\":::\n+\n+1. Once you receive the confirmation that the policy was created successfully, select **Done** to finish the wizard.\n+\n+Once the policy is created, it's applied to the selected applications. When a user attempts to sign up, the Arkose Labs service evaluates the request and determines if it's likely to be fraudulent. If the request is flagged as suspicious, the user is presented with a challenge (like a CAPTCHA) to verify that they're human. If the user successfully completes the challenge, they can proceed with the sign-up process.\n+\n+## Edit the Arkose Labs configuration in the Microsoft Entra admin center  \n+\n+1. Browse to **Home** > **Service Integrations** > **Sign-up protection (Preview)** to view the list of configurations.\n+1. Select the **Edit provider configurations** option to edit the Arkose Labs policy. If you want to edit the fraud protection policy, select the pencil icon.\n+1. In the **Configure Arkose Labs for sign-up protection** step, select the configuration you want to edit and select **Next**.\n+1. Select the app you want to protect with Arkose Labs fraud protection or remove the existing ones. You can select one or more applications that you have registered in your external tenant. Once you selected the app, select **Next**.\n+1. Select **Done** to finish the wizard.\n+\n+::: zone-end  \n+\n+::: zone pivot=\"human\"\n+\n+## How HUMAN Security works\n+\n+When a user initiates the sign-up process, it is critical to prevent automated bots and malicious actors from creating fraudulent accounts. To address this, Entra External ID supports integration with third-party fraud detection providers such as HUMAN Security. This integration enables real-time analysis of sign-up attempts, leveraging HUMAN Security’s advanced detection algorithms to identify and block suspicious activity before account creation is completed. The solution is natively integrated with Microsoft identity infrastructure, allowing for streamlined deployment and management. By implementing this approach, organizations can access detailed telemetry and actionable insights to monitor sign-up flows, fine-tune detection thresholds, and respond proactively to emerging threats, thereby maintaining the integrity of their user base.\n+\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+- An [external tenant](how-to-create-external-tenant-portal.md).\n+- A [registered application](/entra/identity-platform/quickstart-register-app) in the tenant.\n+- An account with at least an [Authentication Extensibility Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#authentication-extensibility-administrator) or [Application Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#application-administrator) role in the external tenant.\n+- Create a HUMAN Security account: Contact Human Security (entra@humansecurity.com) to create and set up a free HUMAN Security account. \n+- The following configuration values from HUMAN Security:\n+  - Application ID\n+  - Server token\n+\n+You can find these values in the HUMAN Security admin console in the [application settings](https://docs.humansecurity.com/applications-and-accounts/docs/managing-applications#adding-server-tokens) page. If you're unsure about any value, contact HUMAN Security for assistance.\n+\n+## Configure HUMAN Security in the Microsoft Entra admin center\n+\n+To integrate HUMAN Security with Microsoft Entra External ID, you can use the Service Integration wizard in Microsoft Entra admin center to create a fraud protection provider policy.  \n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least an [Authentication Extensibility Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#authentication-extensibility-administrator) or [Application Administrator](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference#application-administrator).\n+1. If you have access to multiple tenants, use the **Settings** icon :::image type=\"icon\" source=\"media/common/admin-center-settings-icon.png\" border=\"false\"::: in the top menu to switch to the external tenant from the **Directories + subscriptions** menu.\n+1. Browse to **Home** > **Service Integrations** > **Sign-up protection (Preview)** to start the wizard.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/configure-sign-up-protection.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the Sign-up protection (Preview) page.\":::\n+\n+1. Enter a name for the policy, such as *HUMANPolicy*.\n+1. Select the scenarios to apply the fraud protection policy to and select **Next**.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/policy-set-up-human.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing setting up a protection policy.\":::\n+\n+1. In the **Choose a fraud protection provider for sign-up** step, select **HUMAN Security** as the provider and select **Next**.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/choose-fraud-protection-provider-human.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing selecting the HUMAN Security fraud protection provider.\":::\n+\n+1. In the **Configure HUMAN Security for sign-up protection** step, select the **Create new** configuration, and enter the configuration values you received from HUMAN Security:\n+    - **App Id**: Enter the Application ID from HUMAN Security.\n+    - **Server token**: Enter the Server token from HUMAN Security that you can find in the HUMAN Security admin console.\n+\n+1. Or select an existing configuration if you have already set one up and select **Next**.\n+1. Select the app you want to protect with HUMAN Security fraud protection. You can select one or more applications that you have registered in your external tenant.\n+\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-integrate-fraud-protection/select-apps-to-protect.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing selecting an application to protect.\":::\n+\n+1. Review the configuration and select **Create policy** to create the fraud protection policy.\n+1. Once you receive the confirmation that the policy was created successfully, select **Done** to finish the wizard.\n+\n+Once the policy is created, it's applied to the selected applications. When a user attempts to sign up, HUMAN Security evaluates the request in real-time to determine if it's likely to be fraudulent. If the request is flagged as suspicious, appropriate measures are taken to block the sign-up attempt, thereby preventing fake account registrations.\n+\n+## Edit the HUMAN Security configuration in the Microsoft Entra admin center  \n+\n+1. Browse to **Home** > **Service Integrations** > **Sign-up protection (Preview)** to view the list of configurations.\n+1. Select the **Edit provider configurations** option to edit the HUMAN Security policy. If you want to edit the fraud protection policy, select the pencil icon.\n+1. In the **Configure HUMAN Security for sign-up protection** step, select the configuration you want to edit and select **Next**.\n+1. Select the app you want to protect with HUMAN Security fraud protection or remove the existing ones. You can select one or more applications that you have registered in your external tenant. Once you selected the app, select **Next**.\n+1. Select **Done** to finish the wizard.\n+\n+::: zone-end  \n+\n+"
  },

]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a new how-to guide for integrating fraud protection services, specifically Arkose Labs and HUMAN Security, with Microsoft Entra External ID. The document outlines the prerequisites and step-by-step instructions for configuring these integrations via the Microsoft Entra admin centre to help prevent bot attacks and fake account creation during user sign-up flows. Additionally, supporting image files and YAML configuration updates for zone pivoting have been added to reflect this new content.

After the administrator system is created, add a new secret to that system.\n \n@@ -76,7 +83,7 @@ If SAP Cloud Identity Services is already configured for single-sign on from Mic\n \n ## Configure automatic user provisioning to SAP Cloud Identity Services\n \n-This section guides you through the steps to configure the Microsoft Entra provisioning service to create, update, and disable users in SAP Cloud Identity Services based on user assignments to an application in Microsoft Entra ID.\n+This section guides you through the steps to configure the Microsoft Entra provisioning service to create, update, and disable users and groups in SAP Cloud Identity Services based on user and group assignments to an application in Microsoft Entra ID.\n \n ### To configure automatic user provisioning for SAP Cloud Identity Services in Microsoft Entra ID:\n \n@@ -101,27 +108,29 @@ This section guides you through the steps to configure the Microsoft Entra provi\n \n \t![Screenshot of the Provisioning Mode dropdown list with the Automatic option called out.](common/provisioning-automatic.png)\n \n-1. Under the **Admin Credentials** section, input `https://<tenantID>.accounts.ondemand.com/service/scim`, or `https://<tenantid>.trial-accounts.ondemand.com/service/scim` if a trial, with the tenant ID of your SAP Cloud Identity Services in **Tenant URL**. If the connection fails, ensure your SAP Cloud Identity Services system account has Admin permissions, the secret is still valid, and try again.\n \n-\t![Screenshot of the Tenant URL and Token.](media/sap-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-provisioning-tutorial/testconnection.png)\n+\t![Screenshot of the Admin Credentials section in the provisioning UX.](media/sap-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-provisioning-tutorial/auth-method.png)\n+\n+\t![Screenshot of the SAP Cloud Identity Services admin console.](media/sap-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-provisioning-tutorial/sap-admin-console.png)\n \n 1. In the **Notification Email** field, enter the email address of a person or group who should receive the provisioning error notifications and check the checkbox - **Send an email notification when a failure occurs**.\n \n \t![Screenshot of the Notification Email.](common/provisioning-notification-email.png)\n \n 1. Select **Save**.\n \n-1. Under the **Mappings** section, select **Provision Microsoft Entra ID users**.\n+1. Under the **Mappings** section, select **Provision Microsoft Entra ID users** or **Provision Microsoft Entra ID groups** depending on your scenario.\n \n-\t![Screenshot of the SAP Cloud Identity Services User Mappings.](media/sap-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-provisioning-tutorial/mapping.png)\n+\t![Screenshot of the user and group mappings for SAP Cloud Identity Services.](media/sap-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-provisioning-tutorial/mappings.png)\n \n-1. Review the user attributes that are synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID to SAP Cloud Identity Services in the **Attribute Mapping** section. If you don't see the attributes in your SAP Cloud Identity Services available as a target for mapping, then select **Show advanced options** and select **Edit attribute list for SAP Cloud Platform Identity Authentication Service** to [edit the list of supported attributes](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md#editing-the-list-of-supported-attributes). Add the attributes of your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant.\n-1. Review and record the source and target attributes selected as **Matching** properties, mappings that have a **Matching precedence**, as these attributes are used to match the user accounts in SAP Cloud Identity Services for the Microsoft Entra provisioning service to determine whether to create a new user or update an existing user. For more information on matching, see [matching users in the source and target systems](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md#matching-users-in-the-source-and-target--systems). In a subsequent step, you ensure that any users already in SAP Cloud Identity Services have the attributes selected as **Matching** properties populated, to prevent duplicate users from being created.\n+1. Review the user and group attributes that are synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID to SAP Cloud Identity Services in the **Attribute Mapping** section. If you don't see the attributes in your SAP Cloud Identity Services available as a target for mapping, then select **Show advanced options** and select **Edit attribute list for SAP Cloud Platform Identity Authentication Service** to [edit the list of supported attributes](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md#editing-the-list-of-supported-attributes). Add the attributes of your SAP Cloud Identity Services tenant.\n+1. Review and record the source and target attributes selected as **Matching** properties, mappings that have a **Matching precedence**, as these attributes are used to match the users and groups in SAP Cloud Identity Services for the Microsoft Entra provisioning service to determine whether to create a new user/group or update an existing user/group. For more information on matching, see [matching users in the source and target systems](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md#matching-users-in-the-source-and-target--systems). In a subsequent step, you ensure that any users already in SAP Cloud Identity Services have the attributes selected as **Matching** properties populated, to prevent duplicate users from being created.\n 1. Confirm that there's an attribute mapping for `IsSoftDeleted`, or a function containing `IsSoftDeleted`, mapped to an attribute of the application. When a user is unassigned from the application, soft-deleted in Microsoft Entra ID, or blocked from sign-in, the Microsoft Entra provisioning service will update the attribute mapped to `isSoftDeleted`. If no attribute is mapped, users who later are unassigned from the application role will continue to exist in the application's data store.\n 1. Add any additional mappings that your SAP Cloud Identity Services, or downstream target SAP systems, require.\n 1. Select the **Save** button to commit any changes.\n \n-\t|Attribute|Type|Supported for filtering|Required by SAP Cloud Identity Services|\n+\t|User Attribute|Type|Supported for filtering|Required by SAP Cloud Identity Services|\n \t|---|---|---|---|\n \t|`userName`|String|✓|✓\n \t|`emails[type eq \"work\"].value`|String||✓\n@@ -161,6 +170,15 @@ This section guides you through the steps to configure the Microsoft Entra provi\n \t|`sendMail`|String||\n \t|`mailVerified`|String||\n \n+\t|Group Attribute|Type|Supported for filtering|Required by SAP Cloud Identity Services|\n+\t|---|---|---|---|\n+   |`id`|String|✓|✓|\n+   |`externalId`|String|||\n+   |`displayName`|String||✓|\n+   |`urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:Group:name`|String|||\n+   |`urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:Group:description`|String|||\n+   |`members`|Reference||✓|\n+\n 1. To configure scoping filters, refer to the following instructions provided in the [Scoping filter  article](~/identity/app-provisioning/define-conditional-rules-for-provisioning-user-accounts.md).\n \n 1. To enable the Microsoft Entra provisioning service for SAP Cloud Identity Services, change the **Provisioning Status** to **On** in the **Settings** section.\n@@ -361,6 +379,56 @@ If you have Microsoft Entra ID Governance, you can automate changes to the appli\n * You can [perform a one-time or recurring access review of the application role assignments](~/id-governance/access-reviews-application-preparation.md).\n * You can [create an entitlement management access package for this application](~/id-governance/entitlement-management-access-package-create-app.md). You can have policies for users to be assigned access, either when they request, [by an administrator](~/id-governance/entitlement-management-access-package-assignments.md#directly-assign-a-user), [automatically based on rules](~/id-governance/entitlement-management-access-package-auto-assignment-policy.md), or through [lifecycle workflows](~/id-governance/entitlement-management-scenarios.md#administrator-assign-employees-access-from-lifecycle-workflows).\n \n+## Update an SAP Cloud Identity Services application to use the SAP Cloud Identity Services SCIM 2.0 endpoint\n+\n+In September 2025, Microsoft released a SCIM 2.0 connector for SAP Cloud Identity Services that added support for group provisioning and deprovisioning to SAP Cloud Identity Services, custom extension attributes, and the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials grant.\n+\n+Completing the below steps will allow customers that were already previously using the SAP Cloud Identity Services connector to switch from the SCIM 1.0 endpoint to the SCIM 2.0 endpoint.\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Cloud Application Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#cloud-application-administrator).\n+\n+1. Browse to **Entra ID > Enterprise Apps > SAP Cloud Identity Services**.\n+\n+1. In the **Properties** section, copy the Object ID.\n+\n+\t![Screenshot of where to copy Object ID in the Properties blade of the SAP Cloud Identity Services connector.](media/sap-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-provisioning-tutorial/object-id.png)\n+\n+1. In a new web browser window, go to [https://developer.microsoft.com/graph/graph-explorer](https://developer.microsoft.com/graph/graph-explorer) and sign in as the administrator for the Microsoft Entra tenant where your app is added.\n+\n+1. Check to make sure the account being used has the correct permissions. The permission \"Directory.ReadWrite.All\" is required to make this change.\n+\n+\t![Screenshot of the Permissions screen in Graph Explorer, where the admin is selecting the option to provide consent for the Directory.ReadWrite.All permission.](media/sap-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-provisioning-tutorial/graph-permissions.png)\n+\n+1. Using the Object ID selected from the app previously, run the following command.\n+\n+```\n+GET https://graph.microsoft.com/beta/servicePrincipals/[object-id]/synchronization/jobs/\n+```\n+\n+1. Taking the \"id\" value from the response body of the `GET` request from previous example, run the following command, replacing \"[job-id]\" with the id value from the `GET` request. The value should have the format of \"sapcloudidentityservices.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx\":\n+\n+```\n+DELETE https://graph.microsoft.com/beta/servicePrincipals/[object-id]/synchronization/jobs/[job-id]\n+```\n+\n+1. In the Microsoft Graph Explorer, run the following command. Replace \"[object-id]\" with the service principal ID (object ID) copied from the third step.\n+\n+```\n+POST https://graph.microsoft.com/beta/servicePrincipals/[object-id]/synchronization/jobs { \"templateId\": \"sapcloudidentityservices\" }\n+```\n+\n+1. Return to the first web browser window and select the **Provisioning** tab for your application. Your configuration is reset. You can confirm the upgrade is successful by confirming the Job ID starts with \"sapcloudidentityservices\".\n+\n+1. Update the tenant URL in the **Admin credentials** section to the following: `https://<tenantID>.accounts.ondemand.com/scim`, or `https://<tenantid>.trial-accounts.ondemand.com/service/scim` if a trial.\n+\n+1. Restore any previous changes you made to the application (Authentication details, Scoping filters, Custom attribute mappings) and re-enable provisioning.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> Failure to restore the previous settings might result in attributes (name.formatted for example) updating in SAP Cloud Identity Services unexpectedly. Be sure to check the configuration before enabling provisioning.\n+\n+## Changelog\n+\n+* 9/30/2025 – Released to General Availability a new version of the SAP Cloud Identity Services connector that uses a SCIM 2.0 endpoint. The new version supports group provisioning and deprovisioning to SAP Cloud Identity Services, custom extension attributes, and the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials grant.\n \n ## More resources\n \n@@ -372,4 +440,4 @@ If you have Microsoft Entra ID Governance, you can automate changes to the appli\n \n ## Related content\n \n-* [Learn how to review logs and get reports on provisioning activity](~/identity/app-provisioning/check-status-user-account-provisioning.md)\n+* [Learn how to review logs and get reports on provisioning activity](~/identity/app-provisioning/check-status-user-account-provisioning.md)\n\\ No newline at end of file"
  }
]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response:
The changes primarily involve updating a Microsoft Entra ID tutorial for provisioning users to SAP Cloud Identity Services. Several image files have been renamed or added, and the main tutorial document has been significantly modified.

The core updates to the tutorial include:

*   **Newer SCIM 2.0 Connector:** The documentation now highlights a generally available, newer version of the SAP Cloud Identity Services connector that uses the SCIM 2.0 standard.
*   **Enhanced Functionality:** This new connector supports group provisioning and deprovisioning, custom extension attributes, and the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials grant.
*   **Migration Guide:** Instructions have been added for users to update their existing SAP Cloud Identity Services application configuration to use the SCIM 2.0 endpoint, including steps for resetting and reconfiguring provisioning jobs via Microsoft Graph Explorer.
*   **Attribute Mapping Updates:** The document now includes group attributes in the attribute mapping section and clarifies the use of "Admin Credentials" with the OAuth 2.0 Client Credentials Grant.
*   **Prerequisites and Changelog:** Prerequisites have been updated to mention the requirement for Microsoft Entra ID P1 licenses for group provisioning, and a changelog has been added to detail the release of the SCIM 2.0 connector.

ai_summary.Messages: {"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [ { "sha": "b1c4629c38ec990f609f6004857ddd374f75e335", "filename": "docs/architecture/recover-from-deletions.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 73, "deletions": 45, "changes": 118, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Farchitecture%2Frecover-from-deletions.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Farchitecture%2Frecover-from-deletions.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Farchitecture%2Frecover-from-deletions.md?ref=73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587", "patch": "@@ -1,26 +1,25 @@\n ---\n title: Recover from deletions in Microsoft Entra ID\n-description: Learn how to recover from unintended deletions.\n+description: Understand the difference between soft and hard deletions and how to recover or recreate objects in Microsoft Entra ID.\n author: janicericketts\n manager: martinco\n ms.service: entra\n ms.subservice: architecture\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 11/14/2022\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n ms.author: jricketts\n ms.reviewer: jricketts\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n ---\n-\n # Recover from deletions\n \n-This article addresses recovering from soft and hard deletions in your Microsoft Entra tenant. If you haven't already done so, read [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md) for foundational knowledge.\n+Managing deletions in Microsoft Entra ID is a critical aspect of maintaining the integrity and availability of your organization's identity infrastructure. This article provides a comprehensive guide to understand the differences between soft and hard deletions, monitor for deletions, and recover or recreate objects in your Microsoft Entra tenant. Whether you're dealing with accidental deletions or preparing recovery strategies, this guide equips you with the knowledge and tools to minimize disruption and ensure continuity. For foundational insights, start with [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md).\n \n ## Monitor for deletions\n \n-The [Microsoft Entra audit log](~/identity/monitoring-health/concept-audit-logs.md) contains information on all delete operations performed in your tenant. Export these logs to a security information and event management tool such as [Microsoft Sentinel](/azure/sentinel/overview).\n+The [Microsoft Entra audit log](~/identity/monitoring-health/concept-audit-logs.md) contains information on all delete operations performed in your tenant. Export these logs to a security information and event management tool, such as [Microsoft Sentinel](/azure/sentinel/overview).\n \n-You can also use Microsoft Graph to audit changes and build a custom solution to monitor differences over time. Password-less authentication methods, such as [Windows Hello for Business](/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/configure) or [FIDO2 security keys](../../identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2.md), can be used to allow these users to access both their on-premises resources, and cloud resources such as [Azure Files](/azure/storage/files/storage-files-introduction) through [Microsoft Entra Private Access](../../global-secure-access/concept-private-access.md). ai_summary.Response: This commit includes several updates to Microsoft Entra ID documentation. Primarily, there's a significant revision to the "Recover from deletions" article, enhancing clarity on soft vs. hard deletions and restoration procedures. Additionally, updates have been made to "What's new" to include a new public preview feature for converting synced AD users to cloud-editable, and improvements to SCIM provisioning tutorials. Minor adjustments are present in articles concerning certificate-based authentication, Conditional Access policies, and hybrid identity guidance.

  "patch": "@@ -24,6 +24,16 @@ This article provides information about the latest releases and change announcem\n \n ## September 2025\n \n+### Public Preview - Convert Source of Authority of synced Active Directory users to the cloud\n+\n+**Type:** New feature  \n+**Service category:** User Management  \n+**Product capability:** Microsoft Entra Connect and Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync\n+\n+The Source of Authority (SOA) at the object level allows administrators to convert specific users synced from Active Directory (AD) to Microsoft Entra ID into cloud-editable objects, which are no longer synced from AD and act as if originally created in the cloud. This feature supports a gradual migration process, decreasing dependencies on AD while aiming to minimize user and operational impact. Both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync recognize the SOA switch for these objects. The option to switch the SOA of synced users from AD to Microsoft Entra ID is currently available in Public Preview. For more information, see: [Embrace cloud-first posture: Transfer user Source of Authority (SOA) to the cloud (Preview)](../identity/hybrid/user-source-of-authority-overview.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n ### Public Preview - Use SMS as a verification method in password reset flows in Microsoft Entra External ID \n \n **Type:** New feature    "

ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a new feature to Microsoft Entra ID, currently in public preview. Administrators can now convert the source of authority for synced Active Directory users to the cloud. This allows specific users to become cloud-editable, reducing their dependency on Active Directory and facilitating a more gradual migration to a cloud-first posture. Both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync will recognise this change.

Previously listed under 'Group Management', this new capability, which allows for transitioning synced AD users to cloud-editable objects, is now correctly categorised under 'User Management'. This change reflects the feature's core functionality in managing user identities.

ai_summary.Response:
This commit modifies documentation related to hybrid identity and source of authority (SOA) for users.

Firstly, the `guidance-it-architects-source-of-authority.md` file sees a minor adjustment to the alt-text of an image, improving its description.

Secondly, the `user-source-of-authority-overview.md` file has a key clarification added to the "Password-less authentication of SOA transferred users" scenario. It now explicitly states that **the user account must remain in Active Directory for this scenario to work**.

Here's a summary of the changes:

This commit introduces a new feature to the documentation for Microsoft Entra ID. It details the public preview of a capability allowing administrators to convert the source of authority for synced Active Directory users to Microsoft Entra ID. This enables these users to become cloud-editable, reducing dependency on on-premises Active Directory and facilitating a gradual migration towards a cloud-first posture, with support for both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync.

ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the changes:

A new note has been added to the documentation concerning certificate-based authentication on Android devices. It specifically advises that for devices operating in kiosk mode, such as those using Shared Device Mode, the `com.android.systemui` package should be allow-listed. This is to ensure users are correctly presented with the necessary user interface for authentication completion.

changes.author: vimrang
changes.message: added a note for shared device mode

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for certificate-based authentication on Android. A new note has been added to advise users that when implementing this authentication method on Android devices in kiosk mode, they should add `com.android.systemui` to a allow list. This is to ensure the correct user interface is displayed for completing the authentication process.
